title: How to get rid of sleep paralysis - Quora

response.answer_text: There is no cure, but there are ways to make it less likely to happen, which I’ll outline below. First, you need to follow a comprehensive sleep hygiene checklist. I have created one (Insomnia Insanity’s Sleep Hygiene Musts). Make sure you do the journaling part before bed, writing out your thoughts, but I also want you to add what you did that day, what and when you ate, and ALL medication, including supplements and OTC meds like aspirin, that you took. And then I also want you to keep a morning journal. You’ll write down how well you slept, any dreams or nightmares you remember, and whether or not you had sleep paralysis. This will be crucial in figuring out what your triggers are. If you are having sleep paralysis more than once a month, you should talk to your doctor about it. It would be worthwhile to get a sleep study done. Make sure to take info about sleep paralysis with you in case your doctor is not familiar with it, or mention that you would like the doctor to know that’s why you will be coming in (so they have time to look it up) when you call to make the appointment. I also recommend getting at least 2 weeks’ worth of data (details in the checklist) and journals beforehand. If you aren’t having it more than once a week, and have no other sleep issues, it is not worth it to take the medications sometimes prescribed (off-label use) for SP. The side effects and risks are just really bad, and they rarely work. What you can do to to help prevent SP: Get the sleep you need. Sleep deprivation is a major trigger for SP. If you sleep well, and stick to a schedule that works for you, you are far less likely to have an episode.Treat what you can. If you have insomnia or another sleep disorder that is causing you to lose sleep, you should seek treatment for that.Don't sleep on your back. 58% of reported episodes of sleep paralysis happen while in the supine position (lying on your back).Avoid alcohol and heavy meals/snacks before bed. All of these can disrupt your sleep and can cause nightmares, which are both triggers for SP.If you find yourself having an episode, there are some ways to try to get out of it. "This isn't real, it's sleep paralysis." Sometimes just realizing that you're having an SP episode can make it stop.Try to go back to sleep. If just realizing it's SP isn't working, try to go back to sleep. Sometimes it's impossible (I certainly can't do it), but others have success with this approach.Change your breathing. Since you can't move most of your body, one of the options to get your brain out of an episode is changing up your breathing. You can try calming, deliberate breaths, exhaling forcefully, or even things like coughing can help snap you out of it.A little movement can go a long way. Blinking rapidly, wiggling fingers and toes, and other similar things can work to help you end an episode.Follow these links for more information on SP: The Waterloo Episodic Sleep Paralysis Study A twin and molecular genetics study of sleep paralysis and associated factors

Try this just once: The next time you get sleep paralysis, relax. calm down. remember that you are in control and it is your mind playing games with you. remember that it is not going to harm you in any way whatsoever. Instead of fighting the sleep paralysis, let it go on. let it continue. Once you are relaxed and in control and continuously remember that anything scary that you see and hear is your brain trying to grapple with the shock of being completely paralysed. But if you relax, sleep paralysis goes from a scary, demonic, brain invasion to a beautifully lucid, life changing dream experience that beats any drug.  don't take any medicines just for sleep paralysis alone. if that is your only symptom, just try to start enjoying it. it's really very easy (I have had sleep paralysis every day since 2007, not missed a beat yet) and will wake you up feeling better than usual. If you don't fight it and try to wake up immediately, you will wake up in a matter of a few minutes. a few minutes isn't going to change much. remember that if you're scared of the paralysis.  once you get used to this, sleep paralysis becomes a problem when it's not there.

You know when it is happening because you have been there before. You know what happens. You can’t move. You see unreal things. You try to scream but you can’t. The good news is that you can treat it yourself. To get rid of it, 1. Just stay calm and abstain from making an attempt to move or even bat an eyelid when it happens. 2. Follow a good sleep schedule. Be consistent. 3. Avoid caffeine before sleeping. 4. Create a good peaceful environment before going off to sleep. I have been experiencing sleep paralysis for a long time. It’s actually very common among people. But, recently I have found a way to get rid of it. I just stay silent and calm and a minute after, things are normal. I know there is no ghost holding me down and choking my windpipe. Trying to move will only make you more scared and will make things worse if you are very stressed already (which is one of the reasons why you get paralysed while sleeping). Hope this helps! ^_^

There is no medical treatment for sleep paralysis. Initially many people don't even know that they are suffering from sleep paralysis. Getting approaitate amount of sleep could be a cure for this. During sleep paralysis experience we become tensed and we are unable to move and speak. But in my case I was able to control the movement of my eyes(I don't know if it usual or not). I just closed my eyes and fall back to sleep again after some moments and that's the only remedy I know. Just calm down, nothing is going to happen, tell it to yourself. Sleep paralysis can also be a dream because once it happened that I experienced sleep paralysis, but at a different place, I slept at my home but during the episode of sleep paralysis, when I opened my eyes I was at somewhere else. So just try to sleep back.

When you sleep, your body loses the ability to move, which prevents us from sleep walking. But sometimes your body loses the ability to move when the brain is still awake. This can be very scary. You try to scream or sit up, but are completely paralyzed. This is sleep paralysis. There is one simple trick to get out of it though. Wiggle the tips of your fingers. Just a little. You'll be able to do this movement. Then you will regain movement in your whole fingers, and soon you'll be able to move your hands, and then your arms, and then your whole body will be able to move again. Do this calmly and slowly, and you'll break out of the paralysis in less than a minute. But remember, just start with the tips of your fingers, nothing more

Unfortunately there is no cure for that. However sleep paralysis is more likely to occur by: •	Sleep deprivation •	Changes in sleep schedule (irregular pattern) •	Sleeping on the back •	Narcolepsy •	Medication (ADHD drugs) That is why sleep hygiene is really important: Sleep regularly: go to bed at the same time and wake up at the same time everydaySleep at least 7 hours. Get enough of sleep.Sleep on your right side not on your back.Don’t eat too much before bed.Avoid alcohol.Comfort yourself. Try not to be scared of it “It’s jus sleep paralysis”, try to realize it and reason with it.When the sleep paralysis occur try to move with your eyes or fingers. Movement can help.

My psychiatrist tells me there is no cure for sleep paralysis, it is a very common problem. I had a sleep problem called REM disorder which caused to have bizarre, violent dreams where I would thrash around kicking and punching. Medication helped me to curb this behavior and also pretty much stopped nighttime paralysis, but no medication is prescribed specifically for sleep paralysis of (according to my doctor.) I still experience it often when I take naps in the afternoon. My psychiatrist’s answer to that was simple - stop taking naps. (My sleep doctor told me that it has been shown that there is some correlation between sleep paralysis and apnea, but treatment for that did not help with paralysis.)

Most people experience sleep paralysis something like this :  Or sometimes we feel something like this :  when we feel whole of our body is under high pressure. Good thing is it's just a state of unconsciousness between wakefulness and sleep when we cannot move inspite of trying and it isn't harmful to our body. I experienced it once and that time I knew nothing about it and I surely was terrified. It can occur due to many reasons like Lack of sleep.Bipolar disorder.Stress.Change in sleep schedule or place.Narcolepsy .Night time leg cramps.Etc. If it happens once in a while it's fine and happens to most of us. However, if you are constantly getting these, you must consult a sleep disorder specialist. Treatment of any of the reasons above can help to get rid of it.

If you want to avoid sleep paralysis, make sure you sleep healthily and at regular intervals, as far as you are able. Irregular sleep increases the risk of sleep paralysis. Also, make sure to not sleep belly up on your back, since most episodes of sleep paralysis occur when you do. If you still fall into sleep paralysis and want to get out, first of all, try staying calm and relaxed. What happens isn’t actually real, try and remember that! Then focus intensely on some small body part, like one of your fingers, and try to wiggle it even slightly. Usually you will be able to slightly move it after some tries, and then you might be able to start moving your other fingers, your hand, your arm, until finally, you wake up and escape it.

I don't know if there is any real way to get rid of sleep paralysis. I can tell you what I did. For me it was pretty vague what was real and what was dream when I was undergoing sleep paralysis. I had to know. It might seem quite weird but I started to keep pen and paper beside my pillow to resolve this. But I didn't go through sleep paralysis after that for months. I had it once after a long time. Unfortunately, I was not prepared with pen and paper this time. If your case is serious, you should consult someone experienced in this field. I know how dreadful it can be. I am even not sure if it was something else.But luckily it was not persistent in my case.

Sleep Paralysis factors that may be linked to sleep paralysis include: Lack of sleepSleep schedule that changesMental conditions such as stress or bipolar disorderSleeping on the backOther sleep problems such as narcolepsy or nighttime leg crampsUse of certain medications, such as those for ADHDSubstance abuseThese treatments may include the following: Improving sleep habits -- such as making sure you get six to eight hours of sleep each nightUsing antidepressant medication if it is prescribed to help regulate sleep cyclesTreating any mental health problems that may contribute to sleep paralysisTreating any other sleep disorders, such as narcolepsy or leg cramps
